Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO

catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3

2

div.h1:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

div.h2:
ABSTRACT
Formulae display:
?
Mathematical formulae have been encoded as MathML and are displayed in this HTML version using MathJax in order to improve their display. Uncheck the box to turn MathJax off. This feature requires Javascript. Click on a formula to zoom.

div.p:
In this work, the effect of the addition of vanadium to the Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation (SCO) of NH
3
to N
2
was investigated. It was found that the addition of vanadium significantly enhanced catalytic activity at all tested temperatures. The Pt/V/TiO
2
catalyst exhibited the highest NH
3
conversion (â¼100%) and NH
3
to N
2
conversion (â¼81%) at 250Â°C. The physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts were investigated via Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), NH
3
temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), NH
3
temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO), and in situ Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. It was found that the addition of V to the catalyst enhanced the conversion of NH
3
as a result of the formation of new acid sites. The increase in the number of acid sites resulted in increased NH
3
to N
2
conversion via the internal selective catalytic reduction (i-SCR) mechanism. This mechanism involves the SCR of NO
x
, which are formed by the oxidation of NH
3
. Based on experimental results and analyses of the catalysts modified by the addition of V, it was shown that there was a close relation between reaction selectivity and the surface oxygen species of the catalyst and N
2
yield. Furthermore, the addition of V increased the durability of SO
2
by inhibiting the formation of ammonium bisulfate (ABS).
KEYWORDS:

At present, the most important sources of ammonia emissions are the NO
x
removal facilities in which ammonia is used as a reducing agent for the conversion of NO
x
to N
2
, as shown in Equations (1) and (2) [
1â5
],
(1)
4
N
O
+
4
N
H
3
+
O
2
â
4
N
2
+
6
H
2
O
.
(1)
(2)
2
N
O
+
4
N
H
3
+
O
2
â
3
N
2
+
6
H
2
O
.
(2)

The removal of ammonia from industries is a very important issue as it is an environmental pollutant and hazardous to human life. Selective catalytic oxidation (SCO) of ammonia to nitrogen (Equation 3) is potentially a technology ideal for the elimination of gaseous ammonia from exhaust gases that are emitted by NO
x
removal facilities.
(3)
4
N
H
3
+
3
O
2
â
2
N
2
+
6
H
2
O
(3)

In recent years, many SCO catalysts have been reported. Catalytic materials evaluated for the SCO reaction of ammonia can be classified into two groups, viz. transition metal oxides and noble metal catalysts.

Transition metal oxides reportedly exhibit excellent activities in the SCO reaction of NH
3
to N
2
in the temperature range of 573â623â K [
6â12
]. Several transition metal catalysts such as CuO [
6
], MnO
2
[
7
], CoO
3
[
8
], MoO
3
[
9
], and CeO
2
[
10â12
] have been found to exhibit excellent N
2
selectivity in this reaction. Recently, Zhang et al. [
13
] reported that Cu-SSZ13 catalyst treated with dilute HNO
3
showed superior activity and selectivity in the SCO reaction of NH
3
to N
2
. However, the transition metal catalysts significantly decrease in efficiency at low temperatures and by SO
2
in an exhaust gas.

Among these catalysts, Pt/Al
2
O
3
has been found to be the superior active catalyst for the SCO of NH
3
[
19â22
]. However, this catalyst exhibits low N
2
selectivity because of its high oxidation ability. Li et al. [
19
] have investigated the catalytic activity of Pt, Pd, and Ru deposited on Al
2
O
3
and ZSM-5 for the NH
3
SCO reaction and found that the Pt catalyst exhibited excellent NH
3
conversion at 97% with an N
2
selectivity of 36% at 300Â°C. Besides the high ammonia conversion rate, the selective conversion of ammonia to nitrogen is a very important issue; for an effective SCO reaction, both appropriate oxidation conditions and an efficient catalyst system are required.

In recent years, several reaction mechanisms have been reported for the different types of SCO catalysts, such as the imide mechanism proposed for Pt- and Ru-based catalysts. Zawadzki et al. [
23
] have reported that NH
3
first reacts on the surface of the catalyst with atomic oxygen to form an imide species, which further reacts with atomic oxygen to form a nitrosyl intermediate. Subsequently, the nitrosyl intermediate is converted into N
2
and N
2
O.

Another mechanism proposed for the SCO reaction is the internal selective catalytic reduction (i-SCR) mechanism, which consists of two steps. In the first step (Equation 4), ammonia is converted to NO
x
. In the second step, either of the transformations outlined in Equation (1) or Equation (2) occur, i.e. NO
x
reacts with ammonia in an SCR reaction.
(4)
4
N
H
3
+
5
O
2
â
4
N
O
+
6
H
2
O
(4)

The abovementioned i-SCR mechanism has been proposed for noble metal catalysts such as Pt and Pd [
19
,
24
,
25
]. Based on these reports, this study examined the changes in the properties of Pt/TiO
2
SCO catalysts on the addition of V as a promoter to enhance their selectivity toward N
2
. In addition, the correlation of V addition with the SCO reaction was also examined. In the process of controlling NO
x
, SO
2
is inevitably generated simultaneously by the sulphur components contained in the fuel. Therefore, the durability of SO
2
on the various SCR catalysts was examined [
26â32
]. The SCO catalyst located behind the SCR catalyst also requires durability to SO
2
. Several analytical techniques such as N
2
adsorption/desorption with BET, X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of H
2
, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), NH
3
temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), and Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy were employed in this study to elucidate the structure, redox behaviour, adsorption & desorption properties, and oxidation state of the Pt/V/TiO
2
catalysts.

The V-doped Pt/TiO
2
catalyst used in this study was made by a wet impregnation method using G-5 support, which is a commercial anatase TiO
2
supplied by Cristal Global Co. To prepare the V/TiO
2
catalysts, ammonium metavanadate (NH
4
VO
3
, purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co.) was dissolved in distilled water at 80Â°C. The solubility of ammonium metavanadate in water increased with the addition of small amounts of oxalic acid while stirring, until the pH became 2.5. Subsequently, the TiO
2
support was added and stirred for 0.5â h before removing the moisture by evaporation at 70Â°C using a rotary vacuum evaporator. The product was then dried at 110Â°C overnight. Next, the catalyst was calcined in air for 4â h at 400Â°C. For Pt/TiO
2
catalysts, platinum hydroxide [Pt(OH)
2
; SNS Co.] was dissolved in distilled water. This solution was made by adding TiO
2
support, using the above-mentioned method. In the case of the Pt catalyst, reduction at 600Â°C using 30% H
2
/N
2
gas for 1â h followed. The Pt/V/TiO
2
catalyst was prepared by impregnation of platinum hydroxide solution and V/TiO
2
support, following the same support method above. All the above catalysts were ground and sieved through a 40â50 mesh. The following notation has been used to refer to the prepared catalysts: 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
, where
x
refers to the wt% of V.

The surface area of the Pt/TiO
2
catalysts was determined by physical nitrogen adsorption at â196Â°C using an ASAP 2010 (Micrometrics) instrument. The specific surface area was analysed by using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model. X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out using Cu KÎ± (
Î»
=â1.5056 Ã ) radiation, and the catalysts were run at 2
Î¸
=â20â90Â°, with a step size of 0.1Â° and time step of 1.0 s, using an XâPert PRO MRD (PANalytical). X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis was performed using an ESCALAB 210 instrument (VG Scientific) with monochromatic Al KÎ± (1486.6â eV) as the excitation source. The samples were dried at 100Â°C for 12â h and then analysed without surface sputtering or etching to maintain a vacuum pressure for the XPS equipment of 10
â6
Pa. The binding energies and intensities of the Pt 3f, V 2p, Ti 2p, O 1s, and C 1s signals in the specimens were analysed based on wide-scanning spectra. Sample charge effects were eliminated by correcting the observed spectra and using a C 1s binding energy (BE) of 284.6â eV. The temperature programmed reaction analysis was carried out using an Autochem 2920 (Micrometrics). The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of H
2
was analysed using 10% H
2
/N
2
and 0.3â g of catalyst at a total flow rate of 50â cc/min. All catalysts were pre-treated by injecting 5% O
2
/He 50 cc/min at 300Â°C and then cooled down to 60Â°C. The catalyst was placed in dilute H
2
, and the consumption of H
2
was monitored using a TCD detector in the Autochem 2920 while increasing the temperature to 800Â°C at a rate of 10Â°C/min. The NH
3
temperature-programmed desorption (NH
3
-TPD) measurements were performed with 0.3-g samples of catalysts, put under a total flow of 50â ccâ min
â1
. Before the TPD analysis, all catalysts were pre-treated in a flow of Ar at 300Â°C for 0.5â h and then cooled to 50Â°C. The catalysts were then treated with 1% NH
3
/Ar for 0.5â h at 50Â°C, after which the physically adsorbed NH
3
was purged using Ar for 1â h before starting the TPD analysis. During the TPD experiments, the quantities of NH
3
(
m
/
e
=â15) and NO (
m
/
e
=â30) were monitored using a quadrupole mass spectrometer while the temperature increased to 600Â°C at a rate of 10Â°Câ min
â1
. NH
3
temperature-programmed oxidation (NH
3
âTPO) measurements were similarly carried out with 0.3-g catalysts under a total flow of 50â ccâ min
â1
. Before the TPO analysis, all catalysts were pre-treated in a flow of Ar at 300Â°C for 0.5â h and then cooled to 50Â°C. The catalysts were then treated with 1% NH
3
/Ar for 0.5â h at 50Â°C, after which the physically adsorbed NH
3
was purged using Ar for 1â h before starting the TPD analysis. During the TPO experiments, the quantities of NH
3
(
m
/
e
=â15) and NO (
m
/
e
=â30) were continuously monitored, using a QMS 422, while the temperature was increased to 600Â°C, at a rate of 10Â°Câ min
â1
with 5% O
2
/He. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy experiments were conducted in a diffuse reflection cell equipped with a CaF
2
window, using a 660 plus FT-IR spectrometer (JASCO). The spectra included 30 accumulated scans at a resolution of 4â cm
â1
, collected using a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector. A gas mixture comprising 0.5% NH
3
/Ar, 8% O
2
in Ar, and 0.5% NH
3
/Arâ+â8% O
2
in Ar (100â ccâ min
â1
) was passed through the sample. After a steady-state was reached, the FT-IR spectra were recorded.

The SCO activity tests were performed on a flow-type fixed-bed reactor with a quartz tube (inner diameter: 8â mm) in which the catalyst was fixed by using quartz wool. The temperature of the catalytic bed was controlled by using a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller and thermocouple that was fixed on the top of the catalytic bed. Next, gas mixtures containing 200â ppm NH
3
, 8% O
2
, and 6% H
2
O were fed into the reactor. The total flow rate was 500â ccâ min
â1
and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000â h
â1
was obtained. Approximately, 0.25â g of the catalyst (40â50 mesh) was used for each test. The reactant gases were supplied to the reactor by a mass flow controller (MKS Instruments). In addition, moisture was supplied by injecting N
2
-containing moisture through the bubbler; the moisture supply rate was kept constant by circulating water at a fixed temperature of 45Â°C using a circulator around the jacket-type bubbler. The concentrations of the products and reactants were measured on-line by using gas analysers: ZKJ-2 (Fuji Electric Global) for NO
x
and Ultramat 6 (Siemens Co.) for N
2
O. The concentrations of NO
2
and NH
3
were measured by using different detector tubes: 9L, 3M, 3La, and 3L (Gastec Co.). When the SCO reaction reached a steady-state, the NH
3
conversion and the conversion from NH
3
to N
2
were calculated from the concentrations of the gases, according to Equations (5) and (6).
(5)
N
H
3
c
o
n
v
e
r
s
i
o
n
(
%
)

[
N
H
3
]

n
â
[
N
H
3
]
o
u
t
[
N
H
3
]
i
n
Ã
100
(5)
(6)
N
H
3
t
o
N
2
c
o
n
v
e
r
s
i
o
n
(
%
)
=
[
N
H
3
]
i
n
â
[
N
H
3
]
o
u
t
â
[
N
O
]
o
u
t
â
[
N
O
2
]
o
u

2

N

]
o
u

N
H
3
]
i
n
Ã
100
(6)

div.h3: 3.1. Influence of addition of V on the SCO reaction
div.p:
While preparing the catalyst to which the promoter is added, the method of preparing the active metal and the support is important for the catalytic reaction.
Figure 1
(a), (b), and (c) show the NH
3
conversion, NH
3
to N
2
conversion, and outlet NO
x
concentration over Pt/TiO
2
, V/TiO
2
and Pt/V/TiO
2
catalysts using 0.1â wt% Pt and 2â wt% V for the SCO reaction performed at the temperature range of 200â350Â°C.
Figure 1
(a) shows that NH
3
conversion at 200â350Â°C is increased by the addition of V. Also, the V/TiO
2
catalyst show a conversion lower than 80% at temperatures below 300Â°C. As the selectivity toward N
2
in the SCO reaction is an important factor, it is necessary to confirm the NH
3
to N
2
percentage conversion by calculating the outlet NO
x
concentration as well. Therefore, the outlet NO
x
concentration was measured and the NH
3
to N
2
conversion of all catalysts could be calculated using Equation (6). As shown in
Figure 1
(b) and (c), the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst showed 95% NH
3
conversion at 250Â°C. However, the NH
3
to N
2
conversion was only 51% because a large amount of NO
x
was formed at this temperature. Meanwhile, the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst exhibited 100% NH
3
conversion and 81% NH
3
to N
2
conversion as less NO
x
was formed.

div.span:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

div.div:
Geo Jong
Kim
,
Dong Wook
Kwon
,
Jung Hun
Shin
,
Ki Wang
Kim
&
Sung Chang
Hong

div.p:
Figure 1
. NH
3
selective oxidation activities of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, 2%V/TiO
2
, 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts: (a) NH
3
conversion, (b) NH
3
to N
2
conversion, (c) outlet NO
x
concentration.

Figure 1
. NH
3
selective oxidation activities of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, 2%V/TiO
2
, 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts: (a) NH
3
conversion, (b) NH
3
to N
2
conversion, (c) outlet NO
x
concentration.

The adsorption of NH
3
, which is the first step of the SCO reaction, was studied by using FT-IR to investigate the reasons for the enhancement of NH
3
conversion and NH
3
to N
2
conversion on the addition of vanadium.
Figure 2
shows the NH
3
adsorption characteristics of the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst, which showed the largest NH
3
and NH
3
to N
2
conversion percentages and those of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst which did not contain V. In this experiment, 1000â ppm of NH
3
adsorbed on the catalysts at 250Â°C for 30â min and FT-IR analysis was performed when the system reached a steady-state equilibrium.
Figure 2
shows that after NH
3
adsorption over the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst, positive IR bands were observed at 3364, 3256, 3170, 1605, 1336, 1202, and 1256â cm
â1
. The bands at 3364, 3256, 3170, 1605, and 1256â cm
â1
could be assigned to the stretching vibrations of the NâH bonds coordinated on Lewis acid sites. The bands at 1336 and 1202â cm
â1
could be assigned to the nitrate ad-species [
33
,
34
]. Accordingly, it was found that NH
3
injected onto the surface of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst was mainly adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites, while some molecules were converted and adsorbed as NO
x
. In contrast, after NH
3
adsorption over the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst, positive bands were observed at 3364, 3256, 3170, 3019, 2808, 1670, 1605, 1430, and 1256â cm
â1
. The new bands at 3019, 2808, 1670, and 1430 appeared on the addition of V and could be assigned to the stretching vibrations of
N
H
4
+
on BrÃ¸nsted acid sites. An additional negative band was observed at 2050â cm
â1
for the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst corresponding to the Vâ=âO group. Thus, with the injection of NH
3
, these gaseous molecules were adsorbed onto the V sites, and a negative band was observed at 2050â cm
â1
. In other words, the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst has new BrÃ¸nsted acid sites created by the addition of V, and it is determined that BrÃ¸nsted acid sites are present with the added V. The increase in the concentration of the new acid sites of 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst may affect NH
3
conversion.

div.span:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

div.div:
Geo Jong
Kim
,
Dong Wook
Kwon
,
Jung Hun
Shin
,
Ki Wang
Kim
&
Sung Chang
Hong

div.p:
Figure 2.
FT-IR spectra of NH
3
adsorption of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts.

Figure 2.
FT-IR spectra of NH
3
adsorption of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts.

NH
3
-TPD and NH
3
-TPO mass spectrometric analyses were conducted to study the adsorption and reaction properties of NH
3
, respectively, by using the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts. During the NH
3
âTPD and NH
3
âTPO analyses, the NH
3
, N
2
, and NO species were monitored at
m
/
e
=â15, 28, and 30, respectively. The TPD analysis of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts (
Figure 3
) showed that the desorption peak of NH
3
for the two catalysts was sharp in the temperature range of 100â150Â°C and broad in the range of 150â400Â°C. No new NH
3
desorption peak was observed on the addition of V. Instead, such addition decreased the intensity of the desorption peak of NH
3
. In contrast, the N
2
desorption peak of
Figure 3
(b) increased in size on the addition of V in the temperature range of 200â350Â°C. The NO desorption peak shown in
Figure 3
(c) decreased in size in the temperature range of 150â350Â°C on the addition of V. This result indicates that the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst was processed with Equation (1) or Equation (2) more than the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst in the i-SCR mechanism. The decrease in peak intensities of NH
3
and NO desorption on the addition of V indicates that the adsorbed NH
3
and NO molecules were consumed in the i-SCR, which agrees with the observed increase in the intensity of the N
2
desorption peak. The increased contribution of the i-SCR mechanism on the addition of V is clearly demonstrated in the results of the TPO analysis as well. In the case of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts, the sharp peak observed at 100â150Â°C are among the NH
3
desorption peaks in the TPD analysis. However, these peaks were not observed in the TPO analysis. Compared with the results of TPD analysis, the area of the NH
3
desorption peak had significantly diminished and its area was very similar. However, as shown in
Figure 3
(b) and (c), the size of the N
2
and NO desorption peaks increased significantly compared with the TPD analysis. While the N
2
desorption peak was larger in the case of the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst, the NO desorption peak of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst was larger. Furthermore, the N
2
and NO desorption peaks were observed when the temperature of the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst was low. From TPO analysis, the size of the NH
3
desorption peak was significantly decreased in comparison with the TPD analysis results, and the N
2
desorption peak had increased significantly. These results are determined by the conversion of NH
3
into NO
x
species by injected oxygen, and the N
2
conversion from the reaction between converted NO
x
species and NH
3
. As for the results shown in
Figure 3
(b) and (c), the NO desorption peak was observed after the appearance of the N
2
desorption peaks of both catalysts, due to the lack of NH
3
that can react by mass oxidation to NO
x
species on the catalyst surface and that the adsorbed NH
3
, which did not participate in the i-SCR reaction, was desorbed in the form of NO. The important factor in the i-SCR reaction is the creation of a NO
x
species and its reaction with the adsorbed NH
3
. In the case of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst, NH
3
oxidation forms a large amount of NO
x
. The low NH
3
to N
2
conversion is a result of the lack of NH
3
. On the other hand, the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst possesses new BrÃ¸nsted acid sites because of the addition of V, and with NH
3
adsorbed on these sites, the reaction with the previously produced NO can be carried out. For this reason, it is determined that the N
2
and NO desorption peaks are larger in the case of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst. It may be concluded that in the case of the Pt/V/TiO
2
catalyst, which reacted via the i-SCR mechanism, the ratio between NO
x
species and NH
3
is an important factor that affects the NH
3
to N
2
conversion.

div.span:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

Geo Jong
Kim
,
Dong Wook
Kwon
,
Jung Hun
Shin
,
Ki Wang
Kim
&
Sung Chang
Hong

div.p:
Figure 3.
NH
3
TPD and NH
3
TPO patterns of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts.

Figure 3.
NH
3
TPD and NH
3
TPO patterns of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts.

div.h3:
3.2. Changes in the Pt/V/TiO
2
catalyst and SCO reaction on addition of V
div.p:
Figure 4
shows the SCO reaction activities of 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalyst containing varying amounts of vanadium (
x
=â0.5, 1, 2, and 3). The conversion of NH
3
increased when 0.5% V was added, although it gradually decreased when the V content increased to more than that of the loading amount, according to the following trend: 0.1%Pt/0.5%V/TiO
2
>â0.1%Pt/1%V/TiO
2
>â0.1%Pt/1.5%V/TiO
2
>â0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
>â0.1%Pt/TiO
2
. The 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst yielded the lowest amount of NH
3
conversion at 225Â°C (56%) among the tested catalysts. When 0.5, 1, and 2â wt% of V were added, a significant increase in the conversion of NH
3
at 225Â°C was observed. However, when 3% of vanadium was added, the efficiency of the reaction decreased, and the conversion at 225Â°C was 73%. Depending on the amount of V added, NH
3
to N
2
conversion changed more sensitively than the NH
3
conversion.
Figure 4
(b) shows that when 2% of V was added, the highest NH
3
to N
2
conversion could be attained. As the V content in the catalyst increased, NH
3
to N
2
conversion also increased gradually until V reached 3%, upon which the conversion decreased. The following trend of catalytic performance with respect to NH
3
to N
2
conversion was observed: 0.1%Pt/2V%/TiO
2
>â0.1%Pt/3%V/TiO
2
>â0.1%Pt/1%V/TiO
2
>â0.1%Pt/0.5%V/TiO
2
>â0.1%Pt/TiO
2
(at 225Â°C). In conclusion, the 0.1%/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst exhibited solid NH
3
conversion and NH
3
to N
2
conversion, and was selected as the optimal catalyst for SCO reaction activity via the SCR reaction based on its V content.

div.span:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

div.div:
Geo Jong
Kim
,
Dong Wook
Kwon
,
Jung Hun
Shin
,
Ki Wang
Kim
&
Sung Chang
Hong

div.p:
Figure 4.
NH
3
selective oxidation activities of 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts: (a) NH
3
conversion, (b) NH
3
to N
2
conversion, (c) outlet NO
x
concentration.

Figure 4.
NH
3
selective oxidation activities of 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts: (a) NH
3
conversion, (b) NH
3
to N
2
conversion, (c) outlet NO
x
concentration.

A structural analysis of the synthesised catalysts was conducted to investigate their physicochemical properties, which are subject to change by V loading. XRD was used to analyse the structural properties of raw TiO
2
, 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, and 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts, as shown in
Figure 5
. For the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts, the Pt peaks were not observed in the XRD pattern, and the characteristic TiO
2
peaks were observed at 25.3Â°, 37.1Â°, and 47.5Â°. It may be concluded from this observation that Pt is either highly dispersed as compared to TiO
2
or is not observed due to its low content. It is well known that the major structural peaks of the vanadium oxides are mainly identified at 28Â°, 37Â°, and 55Â° (for VO
2
), and at 20Â°, 26Â°, and 31Â° (for V
2
O
5
) [
35
]. The XRD patterns of all catalysts showed the presence of only the TiO
2
crystallite phase at 25.3Â°, 37.1Â°, and 47.5Â°, which indicated that the vanadium oxides were well-dispersed on the TiO
2
support structure. It has also been reported that vanadium can be incorporated into the TiO
2
structure [
36
].

div.span:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

div.div:
Geo Jong
Kim
,
Dong Wook
Kwon
,
Jung Hun
Shin
,
Ki Wang
Kim
&
Sung Chang
Hong

div.p:
Figure 5.
XRD patterns of 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts with vanadium loadings.

Figure 5.
XRD patterns of 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts with vanadium loadings.

The surface area, average pore diameter, and total pore volumes of the TiO
2
, 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts are given in
Table 1
. The addition of vanadium to the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst evidently decreased the surface area and total pore volume from 62.08 to 26.04â m
2
g
â1
and from 0.2869 to 0.2101â cm
3
g
â1
, respectively. In contrast, the average pore diameter increased from 18.49 to 33.13â nm. These results indicate that the surface area of the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst decreased because the small pores of the catalyst were blocked by the addition of vanadium. In general, it is known that the addition of vanadium reduces the surface area of a catalyst because it induces aggregation of the catalyst at high temperatures [
37
].

div.span:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

div.div:
Geo Jong
Kim
,
Dong Wook
Kwon
,
Jung Hun
Shin
,
Ki Wang
Kim
&
Sung Chang
Hong

h3.b:
Table 1. The surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts.

div.p:
H
2
-temperature programmed reduction (TPR) analysis was performed to investigate the oxidation state of the Pt oxides and reducibility of the catalysts.
Figure 6
shows the H
2
-TPR results of the low TiO
2
, 2%V/TiO
2
, 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, and 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts. The hydrogen consumption peak of low TiO
2
was observed at 485Â°C. This peak arises due to the reduction of Ti
4+
to Ti
3+
in the bulk TiO
2
[
38
]. The hydrogen consumption peak of V/TiO
2
was observed at a lower temperature of 350Â°C than low TiO
2
, because of the VâOâTi interactions taking place when vanadium covers the surface of TiO
2
[
38
]. The 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst showed one hydrogen consumption peak at 100Â°C, which could be assigned as the reduction peak of the Pt oxide species [
39
]. On the other hand, the 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts exhibited a sharp peak under 100Â°C and a broad peak at 300Â°C. The first peak was assigned as the reduction peak of the Pt oxide species, which was also observed for the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst. The second peak corresponded to the reduction in V/TiO
2
. It was also found from H
2
-TPR analysis that if the content of V added to the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst increased, the hydrogen consumption peak caused by the Pt oxide species also increased. In a previous study, it has been reported that metallic Pt is the main species in thermally treated Pt/TiO
2
catalyst. Thus, to convert the Pt valence state of the 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts to metallic Pt, H
2
was injected at 600Â°C. However, as the content of V in the 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts increased, the hydrogen consumption peak due to the Pt oxide species also increased. This result was obtained because the metallic Pt valence state was easily re-oxidised to PtO
x
species due to the strong oxidising power of V. The change in the Pt valence state may affect the NH
3
âSCO reaction. In general, it has been reported that when Pt is present as metallic Pt, the oxidising power of the catalyst becomes stronger [
40
]. Thus, the decrease in the NH
3
conversion due to the increase in the amount of V can be explained by the conversion of the metallic Pt valence state to PtO
x
species (
Figure 4
(a)). The broad peak observed at 300Â°C was assigned the peak due to VâOâTi species, and as the V content increased, the peak size also increased. This result suggests that the vanadium oxygen species generated by addition of V to 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst increased the oxygen mobility available for SCO reaction activity, which is a very important factor in the i-SCR mechanism. Kwon et al. [
41
] have reported that in the case of the V/TiO
2
catalyst, the reaction activity is excellent when there is sufficient oxygen content in the catalyst for the SCR reaction to proceed. Alternatively, the catalytic reaction utilises lattice oxygen in the case of SCR reactions because oxygen cannot be introduced into such reactions. The increase in oxygen mobility due to the addition of V in this study was found to be responsible for the increased selectivity of N
2
as it participated in the relevant reaction following the i-SCR mechanism (Equation 1).

div.span:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

div.div:
Geo Jong
Kim
,
Dong Wook
Kwon
,
Jung Hun
Shin
,
Ki Wang
Kim
&
Sung Chang
Hong

div.p:
Figure 6.
H
2
TPR profiles of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, 2%V/TiO
2
, 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts.

Figure 6.
H
2
TPR profiles of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, 2%V/TiO
2
, 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts.

As mentioned above, the different oxygen species present in the catalyst have a significant effect on the SCO reaction activity [
42
,
43
]. Thus, XPS analysis was performed to confirm the changes in the different oxygen species of the catalyst as the content of 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalyst was varied.
Figure 7
shows the results for the O1s peak while
Table 2
indicates the ratio of each oxygen compound that splits the O1s peak. The binding energy of O1s is typically observed in the range of 530â533.5â eV and consists of overlapped peaks of several oxygen compounds. The first peak observed at a binding energy of 530â eV is caused by the lattice oxygen (O
Î±
). The second peak observed at 532â eV indicates the oxygen species (O
Î²
) adsorbed on the surface, while the third and last peak observed at 533.4â eV indicates either a hydroxyl species or adsorbed water (O
Î³
) on the catalyst surface. The O
Î²
/O
T
ratio of 0.1%Pt/
x
%V/TiO
2
catalysts decreased until the content of V was 2% and increased a little yet again when it the loading of V increased to 3â wt%. These observations can be summarised as the following trend for the O
Î²
/O
T
ratio: Pt/TiO
2
>âPt/0.5%V/TiO
2
>âPt/1%V/TiO
2
>âPt/3%V/TiO
2
>âPt/2%V/TiO
2
. These results have a very close relationship with the tendency of the NH
3
to N
2
conversion. The correlation between the O
Î²
/O
T
ratio and NH
3
to N
2
conversion is shown in
Figure 8
. Wu et al. [
43
] have reported that the surface oxygen species (O
Î²
) is the most active oxygen compound, which has high mobility and, thus, displays higher activity in the oxidation reaction. Lee et al. [
38
] have reported that when there is an abundance of the surface oxygen species O
Î²
, the SCO reactions are successful, although this trend affects the N
2
yield negatively. The correlation between NH
3
to N
2
conversion and O
Î²
/O
T
ratio is shown in
Figure 8
and is consistent with previous studies. This result is also in agreement with the observations of NO
x
concentration (
Figure 1
(c)) and the TPD and TPO analysis results (
Figure 3
). Thus, it may be concluded that a catalyst with a high concentration of surface oxygen species effectively catalyses the oxidation of NH
3
to NO
x
(SCO reaction), and the i-SCR reaction does not proceed to any appreciable degree because of a lack of unreacted NH
3
. This ultimately results in the desorption of NO
x
and low NH
3
to N
2
conversion.

div.p:
The effect of SO
2
on the SCO activity of 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts at a GHSV of 60,000â h
â1
was investigated. To evaluate the influence of SO
2
on the SCO reaction, 100â ppm of SO
2
was fed into the catalytic reactor for 12 or 24â h at 300Â°C. The results of these experiments are showed in
Figure 9
.

2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N

div.p:
Figure 9.
The effect ABS formation over 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts: (a) NH
3
conversion, (b) NH
3
to N
2
conversion, (c) outlet NO
x
concentration.

Figure 9.
The effect ABS formation over 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts: (a) NH
3
conversion, (b) NH
3
to N
2
conversion, (c) outlet NO
x
concentration.

In case of the 0.1% Pt/TiO
2
-ABS12â h catalyst (in which ABS, or ammonium bisulphate, was artificially formed for 12â h), when the SCO reaction was carried out at 300Â°C with NH
3
for 20â h, the conversion of NH
3
decreased from 100% to 87% and the conversion of NH
3
to N
2
also decreased from 51% to 37%. Since there was no change in the NO
x
concentration (
Figure 9
(c)), it was concluded that ABS did not affect the volume of NO
x
, as the NH
3
to N
2
conversion decreased in line with the increase in unreacted NH
3
. In contrast, the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
-ABS24â h catalyst (in which ABS was artificially formed for 24â h) showed no decrease in the reaction activity for 45â h at 300Â°C, and there was no change in the NH
3
to N
2
conversion either. However, in the case of the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
-ABS24â h catalyst, the NH
3
to N
2
conversion decreased from 80% to 64% while the concentration of NO
x
increased with time (
Figure 9
(c)).

Figure 10
shows the catalyst surface in which ABS was artificially formed by using FT-IR analysis. As a result, in the case of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst, ABS was formed on the surface of the catalyst within 12â h in which the sulphate and Sâ=âO peaks could be clearly observed. However, for the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst, the ABS peak was observed only with catalyst in which NH
3
and SO
2
were simultaneously injected for 24â h. To summarise, when V was added, the formation time of ABS was delayed. ABS is formed by the transformations shown in Equations (7) and (8).
(7)
2

O
2
+
O
2
â
2
S
O
3
(7)
(8)

O
3
+
N
H
3
+
H
2
O
â

H
4

4
(8)

div.span:
Influence of the addition of vanadium to Pt/TiO
2
catalyst on the selective catalytic oxidation of NH
3
to N
2

div.div:
Geo Jong
Kim
,
Dong Wook
Kwon
,
Jung Hun
Shin
,
Ki Wang
Kim
&
Sung Chang
Hong

div.p:
Figure 10.
FT-IR spectra of ABS formation catalyst and fresh catalyst in compare ABS reagent: (a) 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, (b) 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
.

Figure 10.
FT-IR spectra of ABS formation catalyst and fresh catalyst in compare ABS reagent: (a) 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
, (b) 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
.

As ABS is formed by the reaction between oxidised SO
3
and NH
3
, an increase in unreacted NH
3
leads to an increase in the amount of ABS formed. If the amount of unreacted NH
3
is small, the formation of ABS is inhibited. Because the amount of the unreacted NH
3
decreased on the addition of vanadium, ABS formation on the catalyst surface was successfully inhibited.

This study shows that both NH
3
conversion and NH
3
to N
2
conversion increase on the addition of vanadium to the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst. FT-IR analysis of the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst showed that additional BrÃ¸nsted acid sites had formed through the addition of vanadium. NH
3
âTPD and TPO analyses indicated that the increased NH
3
to N
2
conversion was caused by the reaction of NO
x
formed via the i-SCR mechanism. When the content of V was increased, the valence state of Pt was re-oxidised to PtO
x
which reduced the NH
3
conversion. Nevertheless, the selectivity toward N
2
improved significantly. The selectivity toward N
2
was excellent when the concentration of the surface oxygen species (O
Î²
) of the catalyst was low, as determined from XPS O1s analysis. In conclusion, in the case of the 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalyst, the ratio between NO
x
and unreacted NH
3
formed by the oxidation of NH
3
was consistent with the progress expected from the i-SCR mechanism. When 2â wt% of V was added, the product ratio became optimal. Finally, an assessment of the durability of SO
2
indicated that the addition of V was beneficial for SO
2
durability, inhibiting the formation of ammonium bisulfate, compared with the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
catalyst.

div.b:
Table 1. The surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter of the 0.1%Pt/TiO
2
and 0.1%Pt/2%V/TiO
2
catalysts.

%V/TiO
2
catalysts prepared at different vanadium loadings.
